Akame Ga Kill the animation is the adaptation of an unfinished manga about an assassination group known as Night Raid who are part of a revolutionary army that wants to other throw the cruel empire and most characters wield these ancient weapons known as Teigu which have special skills but only can be wielded by specific people.
Story - (7/10)
The story is very simple, tyranny rules a country and the people are oppressed so a revolution seeks to other throw them, a story that has been done many times but even a simple story done well can still make it unique and Akame Ga Kill managesto add a little more to the formula and that is due to the characters. Sadly though, it was rushed to the restrictions of 24 episodes and the fact that the manga is still going so changes had to be made to have an ending within 24 episodes which do weaken the anime a bit but with what they added still manages to leave you somewhat satisfied. 


Art - (8/10)

Like most action anime the animation is fast paced and energetic and doesn't do anything too over the top. The character designs, while simple still managed to have a somewhat distinct design and the transitions of emotions, specifically the villains were done really well when showing their personality visually and that was something I really liked. 


Sound - (6/10)

The sound and music were pretty much very generic and nothing too memorable, it sounded good but it could have been done in any other anime.

The seiyu's were also good but nothing too memorable, a very safe choice to me. 


Character - (10/10)

This is one of my main reasons why I really liked this anime, the characters were so interesting and engaging that they were so likeable. My favourite is Tatsumi and while he looks pretty simple, he had really great development. In the first episode he actually was already able to handle himself and was quite strong and despite not having a teigu he is still able to fight on near equal footing, what I liked was while he was strong, he wasn't too strong as they shown he had lots of room for improvement and each episode you see him get stronger both physically and as a character, he breaks most traditions of a main character and doesn't fall into the typical good guy category. the other characters like Akame, Bulat, Mine, etc are all very interesting and most have some really good backstories and get as much screen time to display their skills. 


Enjoyment - (9/10)

Overall - (8/10)

The show starts showing that it is not afraid to show gore, and it that the overall story will have a dark undertone. It also establishes the "No Character is safe" feel for the show very early into it. this is two things the show does very well in the first few episodes. There also is a huge cast of characters that seem like they all are highly likable when you meet them. Along side these characters are a revolt against the government story, and magical weapons that all possess very unique powers.
This is what makes the show seem so great for the first tenepisodes, but one can tell it was not meant to be 24 episodes long but much longer. The show starts moving at a lighting fast rate, killing off characters extremely quick, thus making the unique likable cast no more then names with no real descriptions other than the back stories we are force fed on the spot. The dark undertones goes away with all the comedy, and do not even get me started on "Justice Girl", or the last four episodes.


As you near the completion of the show you no longer wonder if a character is going to die, Akame Ga Kill beats the dead horse they gave no development to so frequently, a semi main character dying is no longer important or impact , its just a way for the writers to try being different.


Then there is the story, it starts out with Night Raid first starts off training their new pupil, fighting corrupt government officials. Then the fights start becoming against people trying to stop them mainly the Jaegars . Then the fights start becoming silly, we start seeing giant robot looking monsters fight our hero's, some of them literally just appear on the spot.

In summary, Akame started off looking like a 8 or 9 , but the things the show does right, are either overused and become bland, or they totally abandoned ( looking at you giant robot fight).

Shere: Airhead

Mine: Tsundere

Bulat: Kamina

Tatsumi: Simon

Esdeath: Sadist

Minister: Evil

Akame Ga Kill is the best proof of the reiterative use of gore for supplying the lack of development of the story and characters. It is still, not a bad anime, not much al least.
Story and Characters  4/10
In this anime, the unexpected twists become the common denominator since the first episode. At first glance, it could mean that the boredom is deleted, however when the twists are continuously dramatic, although they developed differently, they end up being predictable.
We found in the same extent drama, gore, and ecchi; even though the gore meets the expectation of horrifying tirelessly, theecchi is exaggerated and poorly made with forced scenes for the sake of fanservice -although part of the public can like it- I was not enthusiastic about it. The drama, following the line of ecchi, is prolonged until the end, leaving us with a hole in the heart and a lot of things to say.



I found two essential elements in the story’s development: the concept of justice and the bond of friendship. The first is deductible from the synopsis, is the spine of the series: The intensity of the characters believing in justice is what consolidates the story. The bond of friendship it is the strongest point of the anime at a human level, also, it was the catalyst of the drama.


The controversial end is one of the hardest blows for the viewer, but seeing the abuse of tragic situations It does not seem so farfetched.


I conclude this section with the two aspects which I hate the most: the lack of development in the personalities and the almost-love relationships appearing. Because it is how they are: They just appear. About the personalities, all of them drowns below the fanservice, the tragedy, and the free action. There is no time left to delve into characters  or to understand how they feel because the jump between the action scenes is so fast, and for the same reason, I did not enjoy the drama: there was no pause so that the viewer could think what was happening. Enjoyment 5/10


Watching Akame Ga Kill was exhausting. Although the strokes of absurd comedy helped to endure it, it was not till the end when I felt that I wanted to discover what would happen in the next episode. 

Probably you are going to enjoy it if you like fanservice or if you end up having a crush with some of the characters, nevertheless, do not search for consolidate personalities, a coherent development or a balance between drama and comedy. You could say that this anime has it all yet it feels like nothing. 


SPANISH REVIEW


Akame Ga Kill es la mejor prueba del reiterado uso del gore gratuito para suplir la carencia de desarrollo en la historia y en los personajes. Aún así no es un mal anime, no del todo.


Historia y personajes 4/10


En este anime los giros inesperados se convierten en el denominador común desde el episodio uno. A primera vista podría significar que el aburrimiento queda eliminado, sin embargo cuando los cambios son siempre dramáticos, aunque llevados de diversas maneras, terminan siendo predecibles.


Encontramos en la misma medida drama, gore y ecchi; y aunque el gore cumple la expectativa de horrorizar sin cansar, el ecchi me pareció sobreexagerado y muy mal llevado; escenas y situaciones forzadas únicamente para un fanservice que bien puede gustar a una parte del público, a mí no me entusiasmó. El drama, siguiendo la línea del ecchi, se alarga hasta el final de la serie, donde nos deja con un agujero en el corazón y muchas cosas que decir.


Encuentro dos elementos clave en el desarrollo de la historia: el concepto de justicia y el vínculo de amistad. El primero es deducible a partir de la sinopsis, es la columna vertebral de toda la serie: la intensidad con la que viven la justicia nuestros protagonistas es la que hace evolucionar el argumento de forma consistente. El vínculo de amistad es, sin demasiados artificios, el otro fuerte del anime en cuanto a nivel humano; y además será el elemento catalizador del drama.


El final, controversial como poco, es uno de los golpes más duros para el espectador, aunque viendo el abuso de situaciones trágicas no parece tan descabellado.


Termino este apartado con dos de los aspectos que menos me gustaron del anime: la carencia de desarrollo de personalidades y las relaciones casi-románticas que aparecen. Porque es así: aparecen. No se desarrollan ni crecen, simplemente ocurren imprevisiblemente y sin mucho sentido, y acaban diluyéndose junto a la incredulidad que provocan, pues con tanta desdicha uno ya ni piensa si lo que está viendo es coherente o no. Respecto a las personalidades, todas ellas quedan hundidas y camufladas bajo el fanservice, la tragedia y la acción gratuita. No queda tiempo para profundizar en el pasado de los personajes o en entender cómo se sienten, porque el salto entre escenas de acción es demasiado rápido, y por la misma razón, ni siquiera llegué a disfrutar la tragedia: no había pausa para que el espectador pudiera pensar qué estaba ocurriendo. 

En Akame Ga Kill no queda espacio para el reposo, saborear el drama y mantenerse enganchado; todo es acción, tanta que acaba asfixiando al resto de elementos.


Arte y Sonido 6/10


Los puntos fuertes del anime, sin duda. Para mí lo mejor de ver Akame Ga Kill fue la banda sonora, incluyendo dos openings geniales y una animación que, aunque no demasiado original y siempre abusando de fanservice, nos deja con personajes variopintos y con personalidades que, al menos, intentaron ser robustas. Square Enix ha vuelto hacer lo de siempre: una animación normalita pero presentable. Las personalidades cuadran con el diseño y la paleta de colores, y las escenas de batalla son fluidas e intensas. 


Disfrute 5/10


Ver Akame Ga Kill fue agotador. Aunque los toques de comedia absurda ayudaron a sobrellevarlo, no fue hasta el frenético final cuando sentí ganas de saber qué iba a pasar en el siguiente episodio. Probablemente vaya a gustarte si disfrutas el fanservice o si acabas teniendo un crush con alguno de los personajes, sin embargo no busques personalidades consolidadas, un desarrollo coherente o un equilibrio entre drama y comedia. Se podría decir que este anime tiene casi de todo y sin embargo se siente como nada.

Akame ga Kill is a great display of a seemingly-ideal revolution against power and tyranny. From a conceptual basis, the overarching ideas are very real, and very relevant. We see how power corrupts people; how soldiers blindly accept oppressive instructions and how people kill for the sake of killing. AgK mirrors many military regimes in modern society - we have countless documented tortures and mass killings simply because it was either their job or they were given free reign to do so. I thought of the Iraq War more than a few times as I was watching this movie. 
One character - a soldier workingfor the oppressive kingdom, who really hasn't done anything bad on-screen - mentions he joined the dictatorship to change the system from within. While he sounds completely sane and logical, the audience is pitted against him instantly, specifically because they know that any involvement in working for evil makes you part of the evil; and the creators have done a great job in leading the audience up to this pattern of thinking.


Other concepts to do with justice are very well thought out here; and the audience grows quickly throughout these 24 well-paced episodes to validate or invalidate each character's proposed notion of justice.


Art: Camera work was absolutely great, with the art sufficiently engaging the watcher, not frustrating them, and allowing them to appreciate every drawn scene. Fan-service was toned right back when the plot needed focusing which was great. 


AgK did fairly well to keep the tables even in the fighting. The fights were enjoyable from start to finish.


The best audio was best during fights, and even then it was mediocre. I really think that there was a constant discrepancy between what was drawn and what was required. 


Good characters, the male lead died, which is always refreshing (cruel, I know) and Akame wasn't validated. No fame or history books for assassins. This was consistent with the episodes - "everybody knew what they were getting into" - and is totally true.
